name: OperatorFabric Core
description:
OperatorFabric is a modular, extensible, industrial-strength platform for use in electricity, water, and other utility operations. 
It aims to facilitate operational activities for utilities in two ways: 
- Centralize real time business events in a single place to avoid having multiple screens/software solutions
- Facilitate interactions between operational control centers

This repository contains the OperatorFabric core program.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/blob/develop/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The documentation is found on our project website (https://opfab.github.io/) for the current release as well as for previous releases (https://opfab.github.io/pages/releases.html).
documentation_interface_justification: The project website has documentations for our APIs, for example: https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/api/cards/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: At the moment, potential users of the projects are all involved in the development so they review the versions on the develop branch, there is no point in having release candidates.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Releases are tagged with git tags pushed to GitHub (https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/tags).
release_notes_justification: The release notes for all releases are stored on the project website (https://opfab.github.io/pages/releases.html).
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities on the project.
report_process_justification: Users can submit bug reports using GitHub issues  : https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/issues
report_responses_justification: So far bugs are addressed in less than 2 months.
enhancement_responses_justification: So far,  a majority (>80%)  of  enhancement requests are  addressed in less than 6 months.
report_archive_justification:
The history of reports and responses is available on  GitHub issues.
https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/issues?q=
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Vulnerabilities can be reported just like bugs, through GitHub issues as stated in the project's community documentation: https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/community/#_reporting_bugs_or_vulnerabilities_and_suggesting_enhancements
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports are not supported.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There have been no vulnerabilities reported so far.
build_justification: The repository contains a configured and documented build using Gradle.
build_common_tools_justification: We use Gradle, sdkman, nvm, npm, swagger
build_floss_tools_justification: The tools mentioned above are all FLOSS.
test_justification:
Every CI build runs the following test suites:
- Tests for the Java backend using Junit
- UI unit tests using Jasmine and Karma
- API tests using Karate
These can also be run locally using Gradle tasks.
In addition, end-to-end tests can be run using Cypress for web browser automation.
test_invocation_justification: The tests are invoked by the appropriate Gradle task for the subproject or the corresponding Angular cli command.
test_most_justification:
Our current code coverage is around 80% (https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=org.lfenergy.operatorfabric%3Aoperatorfabric-core).
In addition, Karate tests cover most of the API endpoints, and we are starting to introduce Cypress tests for end-to-end tests.
test_policy_justification: The reviewer checklist states that tests should be added as part of the pull request (https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/community/#_reviewer_check_list).
tests_are_added_justification:
The reviewer checklist states that tests should be added as part of the pull request (https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/community/#_reviewer_check_list).

This PR is a recent example of a change being submitted with the accompanying tests: https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/pull/1037
tests_documented_added_justification: The reviewer checklist states that tests should be added as part of the pull request (https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/community/#_reviewer_check_list).
warnings_justification: We use Sonarcloud to report bugs, style and code duplication. We also use linters (tslint, IDE plugins) for common mistakes.
warnings_fixed_justification: We log github issues to address warnings and handle them in a timely fashion.
warnings_strict_justification:
Sonar analysis is run on each pull request and the reviewer is responsible for making sure all relevant warnings are fixed, as described in the reviewer checklist.
We will look into enabling the strict mode for Angular.
crypto_published_justification: We rely on open-source software using standard algorithms.
crypto_call_justification: We rely on open-source software using standard algorithms.
crypto_floss_justification: We rely on cryptography mostly for authentication. The project can rely on any OIDC-compliant authentication provider, Keycloak (FLOSS) being the default.
crypto_keylength_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
crypto_working_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
crypto_pfs_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
crypto_random_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
delivery_mitm_justification:
Our jars are signed before publication to Maven Central.
Our Docker images are pushed to DockerHub over https.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There have been no publicly known security vulnerabilities in the project itself.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica:
There have been no publicly known security vulnerabilities in the project itself.
Additionally, we use a bot to make sure we stay up to date on our dependencies, which should reduce the risk of vulnerabilities. We are experimenting with another bot to get warnings about new vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_justification: In addition with running SonarQube locally the project is analyzed on SonarCloud as part of every build (https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=org.lfenergy.operatorfabric%3Aoperatorfabric-core)
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: SonarCloud marks security hotspots and some common vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: SonarCloud provides warnings and we act on them in a timely way.
static_analysis_often_justification: In addition with running SonarQube locally the project is analyzed on SonarCloud as part of every build (https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=org.lfenergy.operatorfabric%3Aoperatorfabric-core)
dynamic_analysis_justification: We do not have any dynamic analysis tool. We have an automated test suite with around 80% code coverage and 70% branch coverage, and the inputs used in tests are random when possible.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No vulnerabilities have been reported on the project.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The purpose of the project is not to implement cryptography so we rely on specially designed software for this.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We have builds including tests running on Travis CI (https://travis-ci.com/github/opfab/operatorfabric-core).
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
We also use Slack
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The only credentials present in public repositories are sample credentials.
english_justification: Our documentation (https://opfab.github.io/), our issue tracker (https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/issues) and our pull request reviews are all in English.
implementation_languages: Java, TypeScript, Handlebars, Mustache, JavaScript, SCSS, Shell
governance_justification: The Technical Steering Commitee makes all final decisions (https://opfab.github.io/documentation/current/community/#_project_governance).
copyright_per_file_justification: We include copyrights (see templates here https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/tree/develop/src/main/headers) in all files except test resources.
license_per_file_justification: The SPDX tags are included in the copyright templates (https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/tree/develop/src/main/headers)
small_tasks_justification: We use a "Good first issue" label on issues (https://github.com/opfab/operatorfabric-core/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22)

name: OpenSSH
description: OpenSSH is the premier connectivity tool for remote login with the SSH protocol. It encrypts all traffic to eliminate eavesdropping, connection hijacking, and other attacks. In addition, OpenSSH provides a large suite of secure tunneling capabilities, several authentication methods, and sophisticated configuration options.
interact_justification: On the left hand side of website.
contribution_justification:
https://www.openssh.com/report.html

This webpage describes the various engagement methods for reporting bugs, or participating in the development process.
contribution_requirements_justification:
The main page https://openssh.com says:

"OpenSSH is developed by a few developers of the OpenBSD Project and made available under a BSD-style license."
license_location_justification:
https://cvsweb.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/usr.bin/ssh/LICENCE

OpenSSH is from 1999, during an era when copyright was maintained per-file.  The result is that components are copyrighted by a large number of individuals on a file-by-file basis. This remains the case, and there will be no effort to unify the copyrights inside a single "organization", because those individual copyrights honor the authors who wrote those files.  The terms and conditions are not even 100% unified -- meaning there is a blend of Public Domain, ISC, 2-term BSD, and such, on different files, but all with equivalent copyright grants to the community.  As developers, we maintain the ISC/BSD freedom on the codebase.  The LICENCE file performs a poor job of exposing this complexity.
floss_license_justification: The BSD-2-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: We do not politicize our copyright choice with respect to an external organization.  Sorry. The BSD-2-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
https://www.openssh.com/

The main webpage has URL's to the manual pages for each software component, those manual pages are very high quality and complete.
documentation_interface_justification: The program manual pages are high quality.
repo_public_justification:
https://cvsweb.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/usr.bin/ssh/

https://github.com/openssh
repo_track_justification:
The concept of public exposure of source repository changes to the public, in a live fashion, was invented by the OpenBSD/OpenSSH project. 
 https://www.openbsd.org/papers/anoncvs-paper.pdf

So yes....
repo_distributed_justification: cvs and git
version_tags_justification: We do not use git for the -base openssh.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
https://www.openssh.com/report.html

additional processes for private discussions: email direct to openssh@openssh.com
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
openssh@openssh.com

On a case by case basis.
tests_documented_added_justification: Not documented.  Test framework enhancements are being done by core developers.
crypto_call_justification:
OpenSSH has to impliment crypto.

No cryptography applications and library can satisfy this condition, because they have to impliment.

I think this question should be removed, I cannot see a way to rephrase it and revamp it, because with "Unmet" it is really trying to say "You cannot do anything more than what is in OpenSSL, the gigantic pig of a library which will keep on acrueing additional volumes of cryptography, which their limited team cannot maintain bug-free"

OpenSSH contains not just higher-level constructs on top of library-crypto, but draft algorithms in test for the future.  This work cannot be done elsewhere.
static_analysis_justification:
Various developers (and corporations) provide their findings on a regular basis against the in-development codebase.

OpenSSH is important enough I estimate every single one of them is in use somewhere.
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
Please remove the "CBC mode in SSH" comment, we disabled aes-cbc modes in 2016, it is a poor example.

Furthermore, there are situations where SHA1 HMACs or key-hashes have no risk.  There many situations with risk, but there are a few situations without risk.  The "war on SHA1" is being run by warriors who cannot distinguish the two.  Please see the commentary about SHA1 at https://www.openssh.com/txt/release-8.6 and notice this is multiple years already, and there are still too many commercial unupgradeable devices using that negotiation so we keep deferring it.

"Met" as well as possible, with pressure towards a better future.
discussion_justification:
https://www.openssh.com/report.html

A couple mailing lists, and a web bug tracker.

name: IPS-framework
description:
Python framework for coupled HPC simulations

IPS (Integrated Plasma Simulator) is an environment to orchestrate complex coupled simulation workflows on parallel computers. The IPS is designed primarily for use in a batch-processing environment, with a batch job typically comprising a single invocation of the framework, calling the individual physics codes many times as the simulation progresses.

name: firefit-rose-ap
description:
The present repository holds the FIREFIT Rose-AP components proposed by Introsys, S.A. which aim to easily integrate generic cameras and image classification processes into a Fiware solution, abstracting the user from concerns such as entity configuration, data persistence, device configuration or database configuration.

The first component, responsible for the cameras integration is the [Generic Camera Node (GCN)](#31-gcn-generic-camera-node).

The second component, responsible for the image classification is the [Image Classification Node (ICN)](#32-icn-image-classification-node).

Due to their [synergy](#4-synergy) it is possible to consider that any solution that implements both of the components is making use of a Vision-based Inspection System. Although this classification depends on the application, it is relevant in the context where Rose-AP stands, since it was designed as an answer to requirements and optimizations imposed and identified by the [FIREFIT experiment](http://www.dih-squared.eu/TTE-FIREFIT).

license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/EthicalML/vulkan-kompute/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: // Did not find license in the OSI list. The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/EthicalML/vulkan-kompute/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
warnings_strict_justification: Yes this is outlined here https://kompute.cc/overview/build-system.html and where practical warnings are addressed, prioritising best coding practices for GPU optimization
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Using cppcheck no vulnerabilities at present
static_analysis_often_justification: It is planned to add as part of CI
dynamic_analysis_justification: It is planned to be added as part of CI
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Memory profilers are used, particularly on tests using the Vulkan DEBUG layers
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Not applicable as not many assertions enabled
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: All medium and higher severity exploits are addressed in a timely way after they are confirmed
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
installation_common_justification: Yes we use cmake and pip for respective languages
implementation_languages: C++, Python, CMake, Makefile, Shell, Dockerfile
access_continuity_justification: Yes, part of LFAI org, outlined in https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md
bus_factor_justification: Yes, currently achieved, and outlined in https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md
documentation_achievements_justification: Yes, best practice badge and achievements outlined in https://kompute.cc/ and in main github repo
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Best practices are followed to our best extent in documentation https://kompute.cc/
sites_password_security_justification: Yes, passwords managed by governing org securely
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Yes using automatic coding formatting outlined here https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
build_standard_variables_justification: Yes this is covered in detail here https://kompute.cc/overview/build-system.html
build_non_recursive_justification: Yes this can be disabled as outlined here https://kompute.cc/overview/build-system.html
build_repeatable_justification: Yes the build system and info is deterministic
installation_development_quick_justifica: Yes this is covered via cmake and pip
external_dependencies_justification: Yes this is covered in detail in this subsection https://kompute.cc/overview/build-system.html#dependencies
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Yes this is outlined here https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/SECURITY.md and here https://kompute.cc/overview/build-system.html#dependencies
interfaces_current_justification: Yes this is carried out and outlined here https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/SECURITY.md
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Yes the CI pipelines can be found here https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/actions
regression_tests_added50_justification: Yes this is covered in CI on all tests https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/actions
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Yes coverage is over 90% and outlined in detail here https://kompute.cc/codecov/
test_policy_mandated_justification: Yes this is outlined here https://kompute.cc/#running-tests
input_validation_justification: Kompute is used to accelerate gpu processing so applications using it would only be possible directly through interface as opposed to through HTTP / remotely
signed_releases_justification: Releases are signed by github and pip
version_tags_signed_justification: Each version has a github tag https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/releases
assurance_case_justification: This is covered  in https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/blob/master/SECURITY.md and in every release where relevant https://github.com/KomputeProject/kompute/releases
